awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for the 2022 Summer Geometry Initiative (SGI), a six-week summer workshop bringing a broad pool of students into geometry processing and related research disciplines.  A cohort of roughly 30 SGI Fellows will complete a week of intensive training in geometry processing research practices, followed by five weeks of collaboration with top researchers in the field, guest lectures, guidance on graduate admissions, and interaction with one another; an additional group of students is invited to participate in only the initial tutorial week.  Designed to broaden access to geometry processing research experiences, the program targets Fellows drawn from a diverse set of backgrounds, geographic locations, and institutions, with a focus on students otherwise unlikely to have access to this cutting-edge discipline. Fellows receive stipends to alleviate the opportunity cost of participating in the workshop.

The SGI 2022 offering aims to develop SGI as a supporter of the geometry processing community and as a model program for computational and mathematical disciplines seeking to broaden the diversity of future generations of researchers. Beyond community-building, SGI Fellows will tackle real-world research problems affecting applications like digital manufacturing, virtual reality, physical simulation, architecture, and autonomous driving using tools drawn from mathematical disciplines including differential geometry, partial differential equations, optimal transport, numerical analysis, and optimization. More information can be found on the program website, at: https://sgi.mit.edu/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Support from this grant was used to continue the Summer Geometry Initiative (SGI) in 2022, a summer program introducing undergraduates and early master's students to research in applied geometry.

SGI 2022 took place during six weeks in summer 2022.  The program supported a cohort of 34 SGI Fellows, who participated in the program full-time; an additional cohort of ~20 students were invited to participate in the initial week.  The first week of the program featured a set of daily tutorials and interactive exercises intended to introduce participants to key theoretical concepts and software tools in geometry processing research, with no assumption on past experience in the field (beyond basic linear algebra, calculus, and programming skills).  The remaining five weeks were dedicated to research experiences, mostly 1-2 week research collaborations led by top faculty and research scientists in the field.

SGI 2022 was overwhelmingly successful, exceeding expectations for the technical and broader impact-oriented aims of the program.  Some highlights are included below:

  • A central aim of SGI is to bring a diverse set of new members to the geometry processing community.  78.8% of SGI Fellows self-identified as members of an underrepresented group in computing or mathematical sciences, and numerous countries were represented among the fellows.
  • After the program, many SGI Fellows reported that they were likely to pursue graduate education (MS, PhD) in geometry processing and related fields.  PhD admissions are ongoing as of this report, and already we have seen 5-10 of our cohort of Fellows continuing to top PhD programs in mathematics and computing in the USA and abroad.  Several SGI faculty mentors reported they were likely to recruit SGI Fellows for their research groups.
  • Similarly to the previous offering, SGI 2022 was held completely online.  The program pioneered techniques in online research-based education that we plan to use over the longer term.
  • MIT EECS has used SGI as a model program for efforts promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) among applicants for our graduate program.  It is now included in MIT EECS's strategic plan for DEI efforts moving forward.
  • Several research projects launched during SGI continued beyond the end of the program, and we are currently seeing resulting papers submitted to top conferences and journals in our discipline.

Readers are invited to visit the SGI 2022 blog for write-ups by SGI Fellows describing some of the many projects they completed:  http://summergeometry.org/sgi2022

Data collection among the participants (Fellows and mentors) reflected many of the positive points above.  Example student feedback includes the following:

  • "The tutorial instructors were amazing. You could not ask for more helpful and engaging instructors. The tutorials were engaging, welcoming and covered a amazingly broad spectrum of topics. Content wise, I think having a different topic each day makes a lot of sense. I felt kind of lost on one of the days, but that didn't stop me from moving on with the next one. The tutorials also gave me a chance to meet and chat with the other fellows..."
  • "There is so much to like here. Obviously, getting to work on entirely disconnected areas of geometry is great; the field is broad and at this point I'd rather get an overview than try to dive into a specific problem. But in my eyes, the real benefits of weekly projects come from working with as many different people as possible. Every week I was exposed to fascinating new topics of mathematics by the other fellows in my group. And after working under five different advisors I know a lot more about my preferred research and management style."
  • "I am extremely pleased with the progress I've made as a programmer throughout the course of the summer! SGI gave me hands-on experience digging into research code, which can often seem incomprehensible without someone to guide you through the process of getting started. It was an incredible feeling to be on the ground floor of so many dynamic projects with major potential."
  • "I still cannot believe I worked with such incredible professors/researchers during the projects. They were all very welcoming and tried adjusting the projects to our skills. Talking and asking questions to them, and learning how they think and do research, was incredible."

Planning for SGI 2023 is underway.  Due in large part to the success of the initial two offerings, the latest version has received overwhelming interest among students who wish to participate as well as faculty who wish to mentor participants in the program.
